92 Patarsco RivErR CROSSING

of traffic, and has a total length of 6,350 feet. The total length of the
project, beginning at the intersection of Shell Road and Patapsco Avenue
to the center line of Boston Street, is 19,650 feet.

The estimated cost of the tunnel and approaches is summarized as follows:



A. Preliminary Expenses. .. ...t $ 53,600
B. Cost of Land, Rights-of-Way, Property Damage, Easements, Razing of

Buildings, Shifting of Railroad Tracks, Ete..................... 400,000

C. Construction Cost:

Substructure—Canton and Fairfield Approaches....... $ 324,000
Superstructure—Canton and Fairfield Approaches. . . .. 1,546,000
Tunnel Const. Cost before contingencies. . ........... 11,439,000
Approach Roadways............................... 173,400
Lighting System for Approaches. ................... 22,000
CONINEBNCIER . « o s w5 v mios 5 Finss smus s s amms & §amas s 961,000

Total Construction Cost............ Yo 14,465,400

D. Engineering, Architectural and other Technical Service Fees. ....... ... 988,000

E. Legal, Administrative, and Overhead Expenses...................... 70,000



Total cost of Tunnel and Approaches Exclusive of Interest
during Construction and Bond Discount................ $15,977,000



Cost of Construction

The cost of the tunnel construction was estimated on September 9, 1938,
by Mr. Ole Singstad, Consulting Engineer of New York, and is divided into
fifteen items of construction and one item of contingencies, making a total con-
struction cost of $12,400,000. See Table 40.

To this cost of $12,400,000 there is added the cost of the elevated ap-
proaches, approach roadways, and lighting system for the approaches,
making a total construction cost of $14,465,400 for the tunnel and ap-
proaches, as compared with $9,836,300 for the bridge and approaches.
Other items of cost have been assumed to be the same for the tunnel as for
the bridge except as otherwise tabulated.

CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

The conclusions which may be drawn from the report on this crossing,
herein presented, may be summarized as follows:

1. The site selected for this crossing utilizes the shortest suitable crossing
of the Patapsco River, southeast of the Hanover Street Bridge.

2. The bridge or tunnel located at this site will serve three primary traffic
